head.title: Can Blacks Afford Not to Vote?

hedline.hl1: Can Blacks Afford Not to Vote?

abstract.p: Paul Milmed letter hopes black voters will not stay home this year and forfeit franchise that Martin Luther King and Sen Joseph Lieberman fought so hard to protect for them

block.p: Re ''Why Blacks Doubt Lieberman,'' by David A. Bositis (Op-Ed, Aug. 17): According to Mr. Bositis, black voters are not likely to turn out to support the vice-presidential candidacy of Senator Joseph I. Lieberman because Mr. Lieberman has been chairman of the Democratic Leadership Council and more moderate than liberals like Jesse Jackson, and also because he denounced the sexual conduct of their hero, Bill Clinton.

Remember, Mr. Clinton was also the head of the D.L.C. Mr. Lieberman's positions on most issues are not far from Mr. Clinton's. There is no conflict between calling Mr. Clinton's personal conduct immoral and embracing his policies.

Re ''Why Blacks Doubt Lieberman,'' by David A. Bositis (Op-Ed, Aug. 17): According to Mr. Bositis, black voters are not likely to turn out to support the vice-presidential candidacy of Senator Joseph I. Lieberman because Mr. Lieberman has been chairman of the Democratic Leadership Council and more moderate than liberals like Jesse Jackson, and also because he denounced the sexual conduct of their hero, Bill Clinton.

Remember, Mr. Clinton was also the head of the D.L.C. Mr. Lieberman's positions on most issues are not far from Mr. Clinton's. There is no conflict between calling Mr. Clinton's personal conduct immoral and embracing his policies.

Given the stark choice between the Democratic and Republican platforms, will black voters really stay home and forfeit the franchise that the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. (and Mr. Lieberman) fought so hard to protect for them?
